qas.question: As an example, whose status was downgraded after the civil war?

answers.text: traditionally free people of color in Louisiana

qas.question: Who were increasingly included as African Americans in the 20th century?

answers.text: people of any portion of African descent

qas.question: What were African Americans forced to share before the Civil War?
What kept the separate status of the traditionally free people of color in Louisiana the same?

plausible_answers.text: free people of color in Louisiana

qas.question: Who maintained a strong culture related to Italian culture?
What culture was known for practicing Protestantism?

plausible_answers.text: the rise of the Civil Rights and Black Power movements

qas.question: What decreased the pressure for people of African descent to be claimed by the black community?

context: After the Civil War, racial segregation forced African Americans to share more of <b2_0>a common lot in society<b2_0/> than they might have given widely varying ancestry, educational and economic levels. The <b3_0>binary division<b3_0/> altered the separate status of the <a0_0>traditionally <b4_0>free people of color in Louisiana<b4_0/><a0_0/>, for instance, although they maintained a strong <b5_0>Louisiana Créole<b5_0/> culture related to French culture and language, and practice of Catholicism. African Americans began to create common cause—regardless of their multiracial admixture or social and economic stratification. In 20th-century changes, during <b6_0>the rise of the Civil Rights and Black Power movements<b6_0/>, the African-American community increased its own pressure for <a1_0>people of any portion of African descent<a1_0/> to be claimed by the black community to add to its power.
